docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Townes, who shared the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physics for invention of the laser, a feat that revolutionized science, medicine, telecommunications and entertainment, has died at age 99, the University of California at Berkeley reported.

headline.main: Laser's Co-Inventor, Nobel Laureate Charles Townes, Dead at 99
headline.print_headline: Laser's Co-Inventor, Nobel Laureate Charles Townes, Dead at 99

docs.snippet: Charles Townes, who shared the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physics for invention of the laser, a feat that revolutionized science, medicine, telecommunications and entertainment, has died at age 99, the University of California at Berkeley reported.

docs.lead_paragraph: Charles H. Townes, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist who helped create the laser that would revolutionize everything from medicine to manufacturing, has died. He was 99.

headline.main: Nobel Laureate Charles Townes, Laser Co-Creator, Dies at 99
headline.print_headline: Nobel Laureate Charles Townes, Laser Co-Creator, Dies at 99

docs.lead_paragraph: GERSHBERG--Herbert, medical educator, died peacefully on January 11, 2015. Born In New York, December 1, 1917, son of Abraham and Rose Gershberg, he is survived by Beatrice, his beloved wife of 46 years and daughters Viviane, Denise and Danielle, son-in-law and best friend Ernst, grandchildren Christina, Victoria, Leah, Taylor and Corey. He got a BS from CCNY and a MS in Zoology from University Maryland. At the age of 23, he received his physician's License for New York and Connecticut and then interned in medicine at the Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, NY. During WWII (1942-45), he was Captain AUS of the 39th Evacuation Hospital in France and Germany. Dr. Gershberg was decorated with a Bronze Star Medal, six Campaign Medals and the Meritorious Service Unit Plaque. After the war he did his fellowship in physiology, chemistry and medicine at the Yale Medical School, New Haven, CT and a fellowship at the NYU School of Medicine, where he became assistant professor of medicine and physiology and then rose to associate professor of medicine at NYU. He was a Consultant in medicine and endocrinology to Hospitals, New York, the United Nations Medical Department, New York, the Human Growth Hormone Foundation, Bethesda, MD, the Office of Professional Medical Conduct of New York State Board of Health and the W.H.O. in Geneva, Switzerland. Dr. Gershberg was a visiting professor of endocrinology at Miami School of Medicine, director of endocrine and diabetes clinics and services at Bellevue Hospital and NYU Medical Center, New York and director of the N.I.H. grant School of medicine NYU. He contributed 133 articles to scientific publications and was an editorial reviewer of numerous professioanl journals including Journal Clinical Investigation and Annals Internal Medicine, Metabolism, Journal Clinical Endocrine, Journal of AMA. He was recipient of the Career Investigator award from the N.I.H. and a State Connecticut Public Service award. He was a member of the American College Physicians, Endocrine Society, Society of Experimental Biology and Medicine, American Physiology Society, American Diabetes Society, American Men Science, Alpha Omega, Alpha Medical Honor Society and Sigma Xi Science Honor Society. Dr. Gershberg appreciated all fine things in life, a gourmet meal, a piece of art, an evening at the theatre. He liked to travel, especially to Switzerland, his wife's native country and to California to visit his daughters. Even in his later years he remained inquisitive. He enjoyed gardening and learning about plants, flowers and all kinds of insects, butterflies being his favorites. He was an avid reader, he stayed up to date with politics and never tired of watching old movies. He liked to laugh and crack a joke or two. Mostly, he cherished being with his family. He'll be sorely missed. His interment with military honors will take place at Arlington Cemetery Columbarium, Washington D.C., at a future date. 1/3

docs.lead_paragraph: MARTIKAINEN--Dr. A. Helen. Of Chapel Hill, NC, age 98, died on January 16, 2015 at Carol Woods Retirement Community. Born and raised in Harrison, ME she was the daughter of the late Sylvester and Emma Martikainen. She graduated from Bridgton Academy, and received her B.A. degree from Bates College, and received post graduate degrees in public health from Yale and Harvard. Dr. Martikainen served as health education specialist with the Public Health Society Hartford, CT and several years with United States Public Health Service, Washington, DC. During service with USPHS, she was assigned to Oklahoma, and an extended assignment as Acting Director Health Education with North Carolina Board Public Health, Raleigh, NC. In 1949, Dr. Martikainen was appointed first Chief of Health Education, Headquarters, World Health Organization (WHO), Geneva, Switzerland (1949-1974). She assisted national health programs in countries worldwide. Retirement in Chapel Hill in 1978, she volunteered with N.C. Division American Association of University Women, United Nations Association of USA, N.C. Coalition of Aging, Women's Issues, Episcopal Diocese of N.C. She was a member of Women's Forum of N.C., Board of Directors for N.C. Center of Laws Affecting Women, Board of Orange County Women's Center, Advisory Board UNC School of Public Health, NC Association of Public Health and Public Health Alumni of Harvard University. At Carol Woods, she served as Chair, Residents Committee for Health; member of Residents Council, Chapel of Cross, Center of Public Policy Research. Her awards include: honorary doctorate degrees of science from Bates College and Smith College; International Award, American Public Health Assoc.; Elijah Benjamin Mays Award, Bates College; Women of Distinction Award, NC Council; special medal from National Academy of Medicine, France; Honorary Trustee Hall of Fame Bridgton Academy; election to Phi Beta Kappa, Bates College; Delta Omega Chapter, Yale University, Listed in WHO'S WHO: American Women, World Health Care & Medicine. She was predeceased by brothers, Reino J. Martikainen and Ernest W. Martikainen and sister Irja M. Bownes. She is survived by a sister, Sylvia M. Martin, sister-in-law, Mrs. Ernest W. (Priscilla) Martikainen and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, memorials made to: The Chapel of The Cross, 304 E. Franklin St., Chapel Hill, NC 27514. 1

headline.main: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARTIKAINEN, DR. A. HELEN. OF CHAPEL HILL, NC, AGE 98, DIED ON JANUARY 16, 2015 AT CAROL WOODS RETIREMENT COMMUNITY. BORN AND RAISED IN HARRISON, ME SHE WAS THE DAUGHTER OF THE LATE SYLVESTER AND EMMA MARTIKAINEN. SHE GRADUATED FROM BRIDGTON ACADEMY, AND RECEIVED HER B.A. DEGREE FROM BATES COLLEGE, AND RECEIVED POST GRADUATE DEGREES IN PUBLIC HEALTH FROM YALE AND HARVARD. DR. MARTIKAINEN SERVED AS HEALTH EDUCATION SPECIALIST WITH THE PUBLIC HEALTH SOCIETY HARTFORD, CT AND SEVERAL YEARS WITH UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE, WASHINGTON, DC. DURING SERVICE WITH USPHS, SHE WAS ASSIGNED TO OKLAHOMA, AND AN EXTENDED ASSIGNMENT AS ACTING DIRECTOR HEALTH EDUCATION WITH NORTH CAROLINA BOARD PUBLIC HEALTH, RALEIGH, NC. IN 1949, DR. MARTIKAINEN WAS APPOINTED FIRST CHIEF OF HEALTH EDUCATION, HEADQUARTERS, WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION (WHO), GENEVA, SWITZERLAND (1949, 1974). SHE ASSISTED NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS IN COUNTRIES WORLDWIDE. RETIREMENT IN CHAPEL HILL IN 1978, SHE VOLUNTEERED WITH N.C. DIVISION AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF UNIVERSITY WOMEN, UNITED NATIONS ASSOCIATION OF USA, N.C. COALITION OF AGING, WOMEN'S ISSUES, EPISCOPAL DIOCESE OF N.C. SHE WAS A MEMBER OF WOMEN'S FORUM OF N.C., BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR N.C. CENTER OF LAWS AFFECTING WOMEN, BOARD OF ORANGE COUNTY WOMEN'S CENTER, ADVISORY BOARD UNC SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH, NC ASSOCIATION OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND PUBLIC HEALTH ALUMNI OF HARVARD UNIVERSITY. AT CAROL WOODS, SHE SERVED AS CHAIR, RESIDENTS COMMITTEE FOR HEALTH; MEMBER OF RESIDENTS COUNCIL, CHAPEL OF CROSS, CENTER OF PUBLIC POLICY RESEARCH. HER AWARDS INCLUDE: HONORARY DOCTORATE DEGREES OF SCIENCE FROM BATES COLLEGE AND SMITH COLLEGE; INTERNATIONAL AWARD, AMERICAN PUBLIC HEALTH ASSOC.; ELIJAH BENJAMIN MAYS AWARD, BATES COLLEGE; WOMEN OF DISTINCTION AWARD, NC COUNCIL; SPECIAL MEDAL FROM NATIONAL ACADEMY OF MEDICINE, FRANCE; HONORARY TRUSTEE HALL OF FAME BRIDGTON ACADEMY; ELECTION TO PHI BETA KAPPA, BATES COLLEGE; DELTA OMEGA CHAPTER, YALE UNIVERSITY, LISTED IN WHO'S WHO: AMERICAN WOMEN, WORLD HEALTH CARE & MEDICINE. SHE WAS PREDECEASED BY BROTHERS, REINO J. MARTIKAINEN AND ERNEST W. MARTIKAINEN AND SISTER IRJA M. BOWNES. SHE IS SURVIVED BY A SISTER, SYLVIA M. MARTIN, SISTER, IN, LAW, MRS. ERNEST W. (PRISCILLA) MARTIKAINEN AND SEVERAL NIECES AND NEPHEWS. IN LIEU OF FLOWERS, MEMORIALS MADE TO: THE CHAPEL OF THE CROSS, 304 E. FRANKLIN ST., CHAPEL HILL, NC 27514. 1

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s budget will seek hundreds of millions of dollars for “personalized medicine,” a proposal that is expected to receive bipartisan support in Congress.

headline.main: Obama to Request Research Funding for Treatments Tailored to Patients’ DNA
headline.print_headline: Obama to Request Research Funding for Treatments Tailored to Patients’ DNA

docs.abstract: Pres Obama plans to request hundreds of millions of dollars to fund research into medical treatments attuned to specific patients' DNA and other characteristics; some experts consider so-called 'personalized medicine' or 'individualized medicine' to be forefront of field.
docs.snippet: President Obama’s budget will seek hundreds of millions of dollars for “personalized medicine,” a proposal that is expected to receive bipartisan support in Congress.

docs.lead_paragraph: The leading U.S. pediatrician group on Friday urged parents, schools and communities to vaccinate children against measles in the face of an outbreak that began at Disneyland in California in December and has spread to more than 80 people in seven states and Mexico.

headline.main: Doctors Group Urges Measles Shots as Disneyland Outbreak Spreads
headline.print_headline: Doctors Group Urges Measles Shots as Disneyland Outbreak Spreads
